snippet: Five years after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market — the plumbing of the financial system — is a big liability as it operates on trust.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column asserts that for all the new regulations governing derivatives, mortgages and bank holding companies, a crucial vulnerability remains in the vast and opaque securities financing system, known as the repurchase obligation or repo market; contends that the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market is a big liability as it operates on trust.
lead_paragraph: Five years after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market — the plumbing of the financial system — is a big liability as it operates on trust.

headline.main: After a Financial Flood, Pipes Are Still Broken
headline.print_headline: Five Years Later, The Plumbing Is Still Broken
